Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2012 12:16PM Sido wrote: AH-MAZING! Yay!!!!!
Posts.Title: FIRST TIME WITH NED! MCTHO rosie06ct

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2011 11:46AM Sido wrote: I'm with you LivingIt.  I feel like I'm surrounded by psychic vampires who want to know everything, every tear, every fear, all the side effects, and how my DH is coping. They seem so sympathetic, so concerned and they won't change the subject unless it is to start telling me about their problems, drawing more and more from me, until I'm exhausted (and usually have to get to class.) When I had my first dx I felt like I couldn't tell people how I really felt, because they wanted good news. Everything I said had to end on a positive note. I began to HATE the question "How are you?" Everyone asks, even when they really don't care or listen to the answer. Even the nurses in the infusion room asked, and if I told them about any problems I had, they just said, "Oh, you'll have to bring that up to the doctor" so they didn't want to know either. Now that I'm starting chemo for mets, I'm getting just as ticked off as I was the first time. I know it is a courtesy, blah blah blah. But I also know that nobody wants to hear how I really feel, unless it they want to feed off it.
Posts.Title: Help, Im boring. Cant talk about anything but cancer. LivingIt Reneepals

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2011 11:17AM Sido wrote: I had my first infusion yesterday and was talking on the phone to my HR and payroll departments about taking a partial medical leave next semester and in the course of the conversation mentioned that I had metastatic breast cancer and that my student loan payments are starting in January so I needed to get my full pay...blah. blah. A man getting treatment nearby overheard my conversation and while I was in the bathroom, approached my husband to give him the "good news" that since I'm terminally ill, my loans would be forgiven. When I got back, the man was gone and all the blood was drained from my DH's face. He told me what happened and said "but you're not terminal, right?" I responded that we are all terminal at some point, but no, I likely have a good chunk of time ahead of me before I'm terminal.  He was so not ready to think about me that way! He knows that it will come, but to have someone actually refer to me as "terminal" really upset him. Even my onco referred to my mets as a chronic condition and never even hinted that I had  "use by" date. Which means I don't qualify to have my loans forgiven. My poor love, he's still coming to grips with all this. We both are.
Posts.Title: Help, Im boring. Cant talk about anything but cancer. LivingIt Reneepals

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2010 10:24PM Sido wrote: I finished chemo in December and while losing my hair during treatment hit me hard, it seems to be harder now.  I hate seeing myself in the mirror, and today I constantly want to cry because I'm so ugly.  I just got a partial wig a few days ago (from Hip Hats With Hair - incredibly nice people), but I feel like such a fraud wearing it, as if everyone knows its fake and I'm just pathetic. I just can't seem to pull myself out of this funk (and I'm already on anti-depressants). I've been lurking on this topic for a while and started taking Biotin last week based on suggestions posted here.  I know I'm just barely out of chemo and you ladies are much further along than I am, but your posts have been encouraging.  I guess I just had some silly idea that when chemo was over, all the SEs, including losing my hair, would be over too. Sido
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2010 10:58PM Sido wrote: Lori, you look great! I'm at the point where even a good 5 o'clock shadow would make me happy.  But, there seems to be more stubble every day so I'm hopeful.  Thanks Jane!  Cooper's just my little sunshine.

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2010 07:54PM Sido wrote: My LE therapist is putting me in a full finger glove.  She says that the ones that come to the knuckle can cut circulation by bunching at the base of the fingers.

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2010 09:53PM Sido wrote: Jane_M, yes, my dog is a longhaired corgi.  Breeders call them "fluffies" and consider it a grevious fault in the coat, which is why I was able to have him. Thank you all for the encouragement!  Jancie, I gained weight too (which I'm working on) and am starting to finally lose my steroid "moon face."  At least a little. Judy, I'm a former smoker too.  How long ago did you quit?

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2011 10:22PM Sido wrote: Dear Amy, I new to Stage IV too (11/11/11). My mets are in my rt lung, rt collarbone and the lymph nodes above it. My onco doesn't seem terribly concerned with the bone mets and acted like they weren't as big a deal as my lung. I start zometa on the 28th. The ladies here are amazing and they'vre helped me more than they could possibly know. They'll do it for you too.
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed Stage IV Mets avjenks8 avjenks8

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2010 04:26AM Sido wrote: Raili, I admire your conviction to take back control over who touches you during your treatments.  I'm lucky to have all female doctors (by chance, not design), but my rad oncologist just left for Thailand and I'm left with one male colleague who is very nice and another who makes me feel very uncomfortable because he's older and keeps insisting that I'll be "cured" if I have a positive attitude. (But that is a rant for another thread).  I feel abandoned and as though I just have no choice over who I see each week now.  Then again, I don't feel like I had a choice over anything in my treatment. Keep standing up for your convictions and putting your needs over what is just convienient.  Be well, Sido
Posts.Title: Does someone literally have to touch your breast every day?? Raili Sido

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2010 04:51AM Sido wrote: Raili,  if your rads center is like mine, your radiation oncologist will do a breast exam once a week during your treatment.  I don't know if everyone sees their onco once a week, or if they all do exams each time.  After the first "staging," the techs only touch a little of my healthy breast to tape it down under my robe to keep it out of the radiation field.  They never touch my radiated breast.  My techs are also primarily women. I'm glad your doctor respected your wishes and requested only female techs.  I've found that they are more considerate about keeping your covered than male techs.  And if the idea of a male onco touching you will make you uncomfortable, you should definitely seek out a female doctor or ask if it is possible for a female nurse practitioner to perform your exams.  You have every right to have care that makes you comfortable and fits your beliefs. Be well,  Sido
Posts.Title: Does someone literally have to touch your breast every day?? Raili Sido

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2012 02:41PM Sido wrote: 41 first dx (Stage 1, Grade 3 TN), 42 at end of tx 43 stage 4 mets to lung, bone & nodes blondelawyer: Gads you've had a f**ked up past 14 months! I'm so sorry sweetie.
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2012 05:50AM Sido wrote: Coolbreeze: I'm so glad to hear that it works for you! I'm getting mine tomorrow morning. It's funny, but I've never hidden my port when it was on my chest, but then again, nobody has asked me about it.  bhd1: It wasn't particularly deep. It was just twisted in such a way that the nurses missed it when the inserted the needle. Often when they did hit the port, they couldn't get any blood. Between the multiple needle stabs and the scars from the insertion and removal, I just couldn't do it again.  Mary: I think mine's going to be purple too!
Posts.Title: Getting a new port in my arm. Does anyone else have one there? Sido Sido

Posts.Content: Sido wrote: Two weeks ago they finally took out the port in the left side of my chest. The bloody thing was a nightmare! It tipped at an odd angle and it would take very experienced phlebotomists and nurses four or five tries to get the needle in the port and even when they did, there was no guarentee that it would work. Every trip to the cancer center was an exercise in torture as 3/4" and 1" needles were repeatedly poked into my flesh and when they missed the port, they would push on the needle and shift it around, trying to find the port. I went back to interventional radiology and the doctor had the nerve to tell me my port was fine. So I went back to the cancer center and told the nurse what the Dr. told me and we figured out a way to do it in one try, but whether or not she could get blood out of it was another question. Of course when I went for blood transfusions or into the hospital, I was stuck multiple times, as usual. One nurse even cried because she knew she was hurting me. So, after 10 months as a chemo voodoo doll, it is finally gone. The surgeon who took it out was the same one who told me it was okay so many months ago. He continued to insist that the port was fine when I was in the procedure room. I told him he was wrong and to take the damn thing out NOW. When the surgi-strips finally came off, I was left with two lovely scars, the insertion one and one below it where he removed it.  So, I've decided, enough with the chest and I'm having the replacement port put in my left arm, just above the crook of my elbow. Has anyone else had a port in their arm? There is nothing wrong with you. You are a human being. Being human isn't easy. - Laurie Anderson Dx 8/29/2009, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/5 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Surgery 9/13/2009 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Chemotherapy 10/8/2009 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Radiation Therapy 12/29/2009 Breast Dx 11/11/2011, 1cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/5 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Chemotherapy 11/27/2011 Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Gemzar (gemcitabine) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Getting a new port in my arm. Does anyone else have one there? Sido Sido

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2010 11:46AM Sido wrote: My hand started swelling and after a few weeks of treatment my hand really improved, but my index and middle fingers swell up every day if I use my hand at all.  I do LDM and wear a sleeve every day.  I hate my glove with the fire of a thousand suns, so I tried getting away with a gauntlet, but if I used my hand I swelled (but less).  I relented and wore the *&@#ing glove and my fingers STILL swelled.  They go down when I wrap at night (considering a Tribute glove) but puff up to some extent every day (and my middle finger is kind of heavy and less pliable than my other one all the time).  It's my dominant hand, so I'm learning to be a lefty. BTW, swimming is amazing for getting the swelling down!  My hand looks almost normal after only a half hour.  Be well, Sido
Posts.Title: lymphedema in one finger! littletower Binney4

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2010 10:23PM Sido wrote: Thanks Binney! I'm hoping to try a different brand soon, but my insurance won't cover it and our Komen grant is pretty limited.  Also the one fitter in town refuses to order anything else for me because she doesn't like any of the other ones.  My other hurdle is that I want a black one.  I refuse to buy yet another hideous, beige glove.  Why does everything we deal with during cancer have to be ugly?  Luckily I found Lymphedivas for sleeves. Sido
Posts.Title: lymphedema in one finger! littletower Binney4

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2012 09:28AM Sido wrote: I'm on Gemzar and Carboplastin (G/C day 1, Gemzar alone on day 8, 1 week off). The se's have been major fatigue and nausea. I haven't lost my hair, but it is thinning. The Gemzar also burned some veins in my arm, so I had to get a port installed.  The good side is that after 3 treatments, my last PET scan showed a MAJOR  reduction in my lung mets and lymph nodes.  Good Luck! Acacia
Posts.Title: Cisplatin and Gemzar, SE please Canchaser ghiagirl1

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2011 11:19PM Sido wrote: Hello, I go by Sido on this board. My initial dx was in August 2009 IDC Stage 1, Grade 3 TN. I had a lumpectomy with clear margins and SNB with clear nodes. I had four rounds of T/C chemo and full rads. I finished treatment in Feb. 2010 and my docs considered me "cured." 17 months later in Nov 2011 they found mets to my lung, bone & nodes on the right side (same as original bc). I start chemo on Monday with Carboplastin & Gemcitabine on a 3 week cycle until April and a Zometa injection every four weeks. I first came to these boards with my first diagnosis, and when my treatment ended, I couldn't bear talking about cancer anymore and stopped logging in. Now I'm back and likely never to leave. I'm 44 years old with no children and an amazing husband of 16 years and a fluffy corgi who always smiles. I teach art history at Bradley University here in Peoria, IL and working to get tenure. I take ballet classes to add grace and light to my life. From the first moment I joined in 2009 to coming back two weeks ago you ladies have been wonderfully kind and generous with your love and support! I feel like I'm back home. Thank you, Acacia
Posts.Title: to all new stage 4 members apple apple

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2012 03:16PM Sido wrote: My tumor markers have always been useless. My onco told me they read normal from my 1st dx to when my mets showed up this fall. My lung nodules biopsied positive and mets were there in the C/T and PET scans but the blood never registered. Just part of the fun of TNBC!
Posts.Title: Mets Quiz Polyana Padiddle

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2012 01:57AM Sido wrote: Penny4cats, that happened with my chest port too! When the IR surgeon checked it the first time he stuck it okay, but couldn't get any blood out of it, so I had to sit there with an anti-coagulant something or other IV for 30 minutes before he could get it to work. They accessed my arm port on Thursday for chemo and it worked a treat! First try, good blood return and everything. The surgeon brused the hell out of my arm but I'm happy with the result.
Posts.Title: Getting a new port in my arm. Does anyone else have one there? Sido Sido

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2012 05:45PM Sido wrote: alesta29 - the Spoon Theory is brilliant! I'll have to pass it along to my friends, but more importantly, it validated how I feel when showering has to wait until I've eaten something and I have to take a break before I get dressed. I've never heard it articulated so clearly before. I manage the nausea and pain for the most part with zofran and ibuprophen (can't do tylenol because the Gemzar plays havoc with my liver enzymes.) I scheduled my tx for thursdays because I teach on Monday and Wednesday afternoons. I also try to take a ballet class on Monday night (I usually only make it through the barre exercises.) Sounds ambitious, no? It tends to fall apart pretty easily and pretty frequently. My friends keep telling me I'll "beat this" or how strong they thing I am and it just makes me feel like I'm bursting bubbles everywhere. You're right krissi, depression plays a big part for me because I'm still getting my head around the dx in the first place.
Posts.Title: Am I being a wimp? Sido rosasmommy

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2012 03:20PM Sido wrote: I hate that "how are you?" has become a throwaway question that is asked in almost every circumstance. I always feel like saying "you don't really care, so why are you asking?" But my DH said I was being unkind. When I got calls about test results my answer was "well, that's what you are calling to tell me, right?"  But now I just say "I'm fine" and silently loathe them. As for the awkward "how are you really" or "what's the prognosis" questions, I just say chemo is tough but do-able and that I haven't been given an exparation date yet.
Posts.Title: oh, hi, how are you? bhd1 bobkat

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 03:33AM Sido wrote: I found bc.org when I got my first dx in August 2009. I went through chemo and rads with a cohort of women who started at the same time I did. I learned about the increased risk of recurrance that comes with being triple negative. When my treatment ended in February 2010, I stopped coming because I just didn't want cancer to be the center of my universe anymore. Now that I've developed mets, I'm back, but sticking mostly to the Stage IV threads. I've found comfort and inspiration here, but as a TN, I get pretty scared too. Acacia
Posts.Title: ...And you are? EnglishMajor keepingon

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2009 10:59PM Sido wrote: Hi, I would like to join too please.  I found my lump in August while putting on a bra and within a week was dx with stage 1 (1.9 cm), grade 3, triple negative bc.  I had a lumpectomy on Sept 17 and started 4 round of chemo on Oct 16.  I just finished my second round of chemo today.  After chemo I have 6 weeks of radition to look forward to.  After the lumpectomy they told me they believed that my tumor grew in about 6 months, which scared the hell of me.  And being triple negative didn't leave me with many options.  I've taken the BRCA test but haven't gotten the results back yet.  I don't really feel like I've been poo-pooed for being stage one, but that may be because it was so aggressive. My next labs are on Friday the 13th, but when I was a kid it was always a lucky day for me. Be well, Sido
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2009 12:39PM Sido wrote: Greetings Lovelies, Been gone s few days because I felt crappy after my second chemo tx on Friday (T/C), but wanted to chime in and say Hello.  I also wanted to mention the LGFB sessions because you get a lot of great stuff, just be prepared because when I went to mine I was a good 20 years younger than everyone else there (including the make-up ladies) and the make-up ladies were really focused on making everyone stick to the schedule (so much so they finished early). I would recommend talking to others who have done the ones near you because I've heard that they are usually womderful.  I didn't think 42 was so terribly young to have cancer (though I'm very immature for my age), but I felt like I was in a room full of of disapproving maiden aunts. Re: Reconstruction:  If I don't have a bi-lateral mast based on my BRCA status (which I'm supposed to hear about any day), I'm going to have the PS "balance me out" from the lumpectomy ftaer radiation.  Instead of filling in the gap, I want him to make the lump side even the other side reduced to match.  I've been a D or DD my entire adult life so being smaller would be amazing for me. Has anyone else here gone smaller rather than bigger? Be well, Sido
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2012 10:20PM Sido wrote: I was stage 1, garde 3 in 2009. They found leision on my collar bone when they found my lung mets in November 2011. I just started Zometa, but my collar bone hurts on occasion.
Posts.Title: connect other with bone mets keephealth cookie97

Posts.Content: Sido wrote: I am on Gemzar / Carboplastin and Zometa cycles for my lung and bone mets. On day 1  I get G/C and Zometa, day 8 I just get Gemzar, and then a week off. The zometa is on a four week cycle. My problem is that this is really knocking me on my butt! Days 3 and 4 after my tx are awful between nausea, muscle aches and plain exhaustion. I burn out easily and have limited stamina. I know that one of the nudules in my right lung was compressing a bronchial tube, so I can get out of breath pretty easily. But this chemo seems so much easier than the Taxotere/Cytoxan cycles I did with my first tx, but I'm finding it just as debilitating. Seriously, am I being a wimp?  There is nothing wrong with you. You are a human being. Being human isn't easy. - Laurie Anderson Dx 8/29/2009, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/5 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Surgery 9/13/2009 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Chemotherapy 10/8/2009 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Radiation Therapy 12/29/2009 Breast Dx 11/11/2011, 1cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/5 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Chemotherapy 11/27/2011 Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Gemzar (gemcitabine) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Am I being a wimp? Sido rosasmommy

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2009 09:09PM Sido wrote: Sue-61: That is my little fluffy corgi Cooper.  He's 7 and my daily sunshine.  When we were hit by a van a few weeks ago his short legs were his saving grace and he only got a nasty hematoma becuase he could run under the van and avoid the wheels.  He's doing really well now, though he's still got a good-size scab. We're warm here in Illinois today.  I'm originally from Los Angeles and it almost feels like a SoCal autumn (warm sun & cool breeze).  I know I'm in the minority, but I'm looking forward to or crisp fall days coming back later this week. Be well,  Sido
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2011 05:33PM Sido wrote: I use MyLifeLine.org, I started using it after my first dx. It allows you to enter "guests" who get alerts when I post updates, different privacy settings (I'm on medium, anyone can see, but password to comment), it has a "Helping Calendar" so if you need firends to help take you to appointments, or babysit, or whatever, there's a constantly updated calendar for people to volunteer (I've never used this), and a new feature that actually lets people donate money on line to help with finances if you need it. You can personalize your page a little bit through themes and uploading pictures. I only really use the update part, but I really like it.  I have a friend using caring bridge but I feel like it looks like a funeral home site (white, peaceful, doves...)

Posts.Content: Sido wrote: I got a private message from someone this morning asking me what scans I'd had and did I have any suggestions for her as she finished rads. I had no "suggestions" for her and felt like she wanted to know what I'd missed or did wrong so she could avoid it. I tried, in the nicest way possible to tell her that I found the question cruel but I understood her fears. She then told be she had prayed to god asking him to grant ME understanding about her questions. WTF? There is nothing wrong with you. You are a human being. Posts.Title: People are un-freaking believe-able... Sido PizzaDad

Posts.Content: Sido wrote: I was diagnosed 8/29/09 and started reading everything I could, but I started finding that instead of being comforting and informative, often what I was reading gave me either way too much information so I worried about things I may not actually have to confront, or talked about recurrance and death before I had started my treatment.  The worst for me was Nordie's At Noon, which I finished today.  Before reading it, the thought that bc could kill me never crossed my mind.  I knew that I had a really difficult road ahead of me, since I cared for my mother when she died of lung cancer 20 years ago, but I never considered that my small, aggressive cancer could come back someday and kill me.  I meet with my radiation and medical oncologists for the first time on Monday and I'm now afraid that even after I get through this bout, I may still die from breast cancer.  Maybe it is beacuse I'm an athiest, but for me, the story of the four women was neither conforting nor uplifting.  I would not recommend it to someone just starting their battle, like I am. On the other hand, I really liked Cris Karr's Crazy, Sexy, Cancer Tips, which gives a heavy dose of vegan raw diets, but also focuses on living and fighting.  While I don't plan to become vegan, her spirit and those of her fellow "cancer cowgirls" have given me a lot of encouragement.  Looking back (or there now), which books do you wish you had avoided at the beginning?  Which helped you prepare for your fight? There is nothing wrong with you. You are a human being. Being human isn't easy. - Laurie Anderson Dx 8/29/2009, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/5 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Surgery 9/13/2009 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Chemotherapy 10/8/2009 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Radiation Therapy 12/29/2009 Breast Dx 11/11/2011, 1cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/5 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Chemotherapy 11/27/2011 Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Gemzar (gemcitabine) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: HELP. Just diagnosed today--lung, liver and bone mets formygirls Heidihill

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2012 09:22PM Sido wrote: Formygirls, I'm a fellow TNBC sister and can tell you that I've learned that stage IV doesn't have to be an immediate death sentence. I was diagnosed with mets in November and after just 3 rounds of chemo, a recent PET scan showed a dramatic improvement. Yesterday we had a TN womam who has hit 5 years since her tx. Get multiple opinions, UCLA has the Revlon/UCLA Breast Center that offers a "Multidisciplinary Program" that lets patients see multiple specialists in one day.  There is a lot of love and support here and we'll be with you whenever you need us. Acacia
Posts.Title: HELP. Just diagnosed today--lung, liver and bone mets formygirls Heidihill
